title: Effects of Resistance Training Volume on Physical Function, Lean Body Mass and Lower-Body Muscle Hypertrophy and Strength in Older Adults: A Systematic Review and Network Meta-analysis of 151 Randomised Trials
authors: Radaelli R; Rech A; Molinari T; Markarian AM; Petropoulou M; Granacher U; Hortobágyi T; Lopez P

sections.abstract:
Background The optimal prescription and precise recommendations of resistance training volume for older adults is unclear 
in the current literature. In addition, the interactions between resistance training volume and program duration as well as 
physical health status remain to be determined when assessing physical function, muscle size and hypertrophy and muscle 
strength adaptations in older adults.
Objectives This study aimed to determine which resistance training volume is the most effective in improving physical 
function, lean body mass, lower-limb muscle hypertrophy and strength in older adults. Additionally, we examined whether 
effects were moderated by intervention duration (i.e. short term, < 20 weeks; medium-to-long term, ≥ 20 weeks) and physical 
health status (i.e. physically healthy, physically impaired, mixed physically healthy and physically impaired; PROSPERO 
identifier: CRD42023413209).
sections.methods:
CINAHL, Embase, LILACS, PubMed, Scielo, SPORTDiscus and Web of Science databases were searched up to 
April 2023. Eligible randomised trials examined the effects of supervised resistance training in older adults (i.e. ≥ 60 years). 
Resistance training programs were categorised as low (LVRT), moderate (MVRT) and high volume (HVRT) on the basis 
of terciles of prescribed weekly resistance training volume (i.e. product of frequency, number of exercises and number of 
sets) for full- and lower-body training. The primary outcomes for this review were physical function measured by fast walk-
ing speed, timed up and go and 6-min walking tests; lean body mass and lower-body muscle hypertrophy; and lower-body 
muscle strength measured by knee extension and leg press one-repetition maximum (1-RM), isometric muscle strength and 
isokinetic torque. A random-effects network meta-analysis was undertaken to examine the effects of different resistance 
training volumes on the outcomes of interest.
sections.results:
We included a total of 161 articles describing 151 trials (n = 6306). LVRT was the most effective for improving 
timed up and go [− 1.20 standardised mean difference (SMD), 95% confidence interval (95% CI): − 1.57 to − 0.82], 6-min 
walk test (1.03 SMD, 95% CI: 0.33–1.73), lean body mass (0.25 SMD, 95% CI: 0.10–0.40) and muscle hypertrophy (0.40 
SMD, 95% CI: 0.25–0.54). Both MVRT and HVRT were the most effective for improving lower-limb strength, while only 
HVRT was effective in increasing fast walking speed (0.40 SMD, 95% CI: − 0.57 to 0.14). Regarding the moderators, our 
results were independent of program duration and mainly observed for healthy older adults, while evidence was limited for 
those who were physically impaired.
sections.conclusions:
A low resistance training volume can substantially improve healthy older adults’ physical function and benefits 
lean mass and muscle size independently of program duration, while a higher volume seems to be necessary for achieving 
greater improvements in muscle strength. A low volume of resistance training should be recommended in future exercise 
guidelines, particularly for physically healthy older adults targeting healthy ageing.
Extended author information available on the last page of the article

168 R. Radaelli et al.
Key Points 
The optimal prescription and precise recommenda-
tions of resistance training volume, considered by most 
experts to be a critical training variable, remain incon-
clusive for older adults.
A low resistance training volume can substantially 
improve healthy older adults’ physical function and 
benefits lean mass and muscle size independently of 
program duration.
A higher volume seems to be necessary for achieving 
greater improvements in muscle strength in older adults 
independently of program duration.
A low volume resistance training program should be rec-
ommended in future exercise guidelines, particularly for 
physically healthy older adults targeting healthy ageing.

sections.introduction:
Even healthily ageing older adults exhibit biological changes 
in the nervous and musculoskeletal systems, resulting in 
clinically meaningful declines in skeletal muscle mass (~ 1% 
per year), muscle strength (~ 2% per year) and power (~ 3% 
per year) after 60 years of age [1 –3]. Consequently, it is 
expected that older adults will naturally experience a severe 
impact on their ability to engage in activities of daily liv -
ing over the years [4 ], which increases the risk of physical 
disability and falls [5, 6]. These factors ultimately lead to a 
greater dependence and a higher risk of institutionalisation 
and all-cause mortality [7, 8].
Resistance training is recognised as a safe and effective 
intervention to counteract age-related declines in the nervous 
and musculoskeletal systems [9 –11]. Numerous resistance 
training programs [12–15], varying in duration, volume and 
intensity, have been demonstrated to reduce the loss rate for 
lean mass, muscle strength and physical function in healthy 
older adults to some extent. However, the optimal prescrip-
tion and precise recommendations of resistance training 
volume (i.e. total amount of work performed), considered 
by most experts to be a critical training variable [12, 14, 
16], remain inconclusive for healthy older adults. A higher 
resistance training volume, compared with a lower resist-
ance training volume, is thought to have a greater potential 
to induce muscle hypertrophy and improve muscle strength 
[12, 14, 16]. The rationale behind this is that a higher vol-
ume of resistance training, through repetitive cumulative 
time under tension during each session, can sustain a higher 
degree of weekly anabolism for muscle hypertrophy [17]. 
Due to anabolic resistance [18], older adults present a dimin-
ished acute myofibrillar protein synthesis response to resist-
ance training compared with younger adults [19], which, in 
turn, may require a higher stimulus from resistance train-
ing to significantly increase myofibrillar protein synthesis 
and anabolic signalling [19]. Additionally, a combination 
of nervous and skeletal muscle adaptations resulting from 
high-volume resistance training can lead to greater muscle 
strength adaptations [20, 21]. This is important to counteract 
age-related impairments, including decreased spinal excit-
ability [22], increased variability in motor units discharge 
rate [23], lower incidence of doublet discharges [24] and 
cortical plasticity [25]. Therefore, a higher resistance train-
ing volume may be necessary to induce specific neuromus-
cular adaptations that translate into improved mobility in 
healthy older adults. However, additional resistance training 
studies are necessary to further investigate the potential role 
of resistance training volume and confirm whether a higher 
dosage is necessary to further induce improvements in physi-
cal function, lean mass and muscle strength.
While the benefits from a high resistance training vol-
ume have been supported by previous meta-analyses in 
older adults [12, 14, 16, 26], there is also evidence sug-
gesting a lack of volume-dependence of resistance training 
with similar results between both low- and high-volume 
resistance training [15, 27]. For example, the previous 
dose–response meta-analysis by Borde et al. [15] found no 
significant association between the total number of resist-
ance training sets and improvements in muscle strength 
and size across 25 resistance training trials involving older 
adults aged ≥ 60 years. Similarly, Marques et al.’s [27] meta-
analysis indicated very small and not meaningful differences 
between low and high resistance training volume on lower-
limb muscle strength (~ 2 kg) and muscle size (effect size of 
0.15) after analysing 15 resistance training trials involving 
adults aged ≥ 50 years. The conflicting data between studies 
indicating a superior effect from high versus low resistance 
training volume [12, 14, 16, 26] and those indicating similar 
effects between both [15, 27] may be attributed to (i) differ-
ences between studies involving participants whose age, sex 
distribution and physical health status varied strongly; (ii) 
a lack of studies comparing well-defined ranges of resist-
ance training volume, such as low, moderate and high; (iii) 
a low number of studies included in the analyses; (iv) results 
derived from different meta-analytic models (meta-analysis 
versus meta-regression) and (v) a lack of operational defi-
nition of resistance training volume (e.g. number of exer -
cises × number of sets versus number of exercises × number 
of sets × number of repetitions versus number of exer -
cises × number of sets × number of repetitions × tempo). As 

169
Resistance Training Volume Effects on Function, Morphology and Strength in Older Adults
a result, a more comprehensive assessment of the literature 
is necessary to elucidate the role of resistance training vol-
ume in physical function, lean mass and muscle strength 
adaptations in older adults, and generate more information 
for those with frailty, sarcopenia and mobility limitations.
Another confounding factor in understanding the role of 
resistance exercise volume is the duration of resistance exer-
cise programs (i.e. number of weeks). Previous resistance 
exercise recommendations [9 , 10] have indicated that low-
volume programs can benefit musculoskeletal (e.g. increase 
in skeletal muscle mass) and neuromuscular (e.g. changes in 
the level of excitation and inhibition derived from a cortical 
and subcortical level and increases in motoneuron output 
and inter- and intramuscular coordination) adaptations in the 
short term (< 20 weeks). As participants reach a certain level 
of fitness, transitioning to a high-volume resistance training 
becomes necessary for medium-to-long term (≥ 20 weeks) 
maintenance and continued progress [9 ]. This involves 
increasing training time with higher training volume and 
load and/or specific exercises to result in additional muscle 
and physical function improvements (i.e. law of diminish-
ing returns) [28, 29]. These findings were supported by our 
previous studies [30, 31] and others [32, 33], which reported 
similar results between lower and higher resistance training 
volumes after 12–13 weeks, when participants are physically 
inactive, but not after 20 weeks when participants present a 
moderate level of physical activity [28]. In regard to physical 
health status, resistance training has been considered one 
of the most effective interventions to counteract domains 
of sarcopenia [34, 35] and frailty [36]. However, recom-
mendations on resistance training volume for older adults 
suffering from these conditions as well as mobility limita-
tion are unclear and remain speculative in the current litera-
ture, supported mainly by studies involving healthy older 
adults. Therefore, it is critical to consider the interaction 
between resistance training volume and program duration 
(< 20 weeks versus ≥ 20 weeks) as well as physical health 
status (physically healthy versus physically impaired) when 
assessing muscle hypertrophy, muscle strength and physical 
function adaptations in older adults.
In the current systematic review and network meta-analy-
sis, we aimed to determine which resistance training volume 
(low, moderate or high) is the most effective in improving 
physical function, whole-body lean mass and muscle hyper-
trophy measures and lower-limb strength in older adults. 
Additionally, we examined whether effects were moder -
ated by intervention duration (i.e. short term, < 20 weeks; 
medium-to-long term, ≥ 20 weeks) and physical health 
status.
2 Methods
All procedures undertaken in the present study were reported 
in accordance with the Cochrane Back Review Group 
(CBRG) [37], Implementing Preferred Reporting Items 
for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) in 
Exercise, Rehabilitation, Sport Medicine and Sports Science 
(PERSiST) [38] and the Preferred Reporting Items for Sys-
tematic Reviews and Meta-analyses for Network Meta-anal-
yses (PRISMA-NMA) [39] statement with registration at the 
International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviewers 
(PROSPERO identifier: CRD42023413209).
2.1 Study Eligibility Criteria
Studies were included when meeting the following criteria 
regarding participants, intervention, comparator, outcomes 
and study design (PICOS): (i) studies involving older adults 
(≥ 60 years; as defined by the World Health Organiza-
tion) with no systematic exercise training background (e.g. 
healthy, institutionalised, mobility limited, sarcopenic, and 
frail); (ii) studies undertaking low-, moderate- or high-
volume resistance training programs, as defined by terciles 
of weekly volume; (iii) studies involving different resist-
ance training volumes and/or nonexposed (e.g. usual care, 
no formal intervention, and waitlist) or minimally exposed 
control groups (e.g. walking group); (iv) studies measuring 
fast walking speed, timed up and go test, 6-min walking test, 
lean body mass, muscle hypertrophy, knee extension one-
repetition maximum (1-RM), leg press 1-RM, knee exten-
sion isometric muscle strength or isokinetic knee extension 
muscle strength (all primary outcomes for this review); and 
(v) randomised controlled or clinical trials.
The exclusion criteria were (i) studies including older 
adults exclusively with acute or chronic neurological, mus-
culoskeletal, cardiovascular or metabolic conditions (e.g. 
osteoarthritis, type 2 diabetes and cancer; chronic haemo-
dialysis, heart failure, hospitalised, osteoporosis and fibro-
myalgia); (ii) studies involving within-subject design; (iii) 
interventions involving any other type of physical exercise 
component (e.g. aerobic exercise, impact-loading, and 
balance exercise); (iv) interventions involving any type 
of nutritional intervention (e.g. protein supplementation, 
caloric restriction, low-fat diet and low-carbohydrate diet); 
(v) studies reporting insufficient information on the resist-
ance training volume prescribed (i.e. frequency, number of 
exercise and number of sets); (vi) interventions lasting less 
than 4 weeks; and (vii) studies written in a language other 
than English, Portuguese or Spanish.

170 R. Radaelli et al.
2.2 Search Strategy and Study Selection Process
A systematic search was conducted by a researcher (PL) 
using CINAHL, Embase, LILACS, PubMed, Scielo, 
SPORTDiscus and Web of Science databases from incep-
tion to 17 April 2023. The search strategy was undertaken 
using controlled vocabulary and free-text terms as pre-
sented in the Electronic Supplementary Material (ESM) 
Appendix S1. In addition to database searching, a manual 
search of references in previous systematic reviews was 
performed to detect potentially eligible articles for inclu-
sion. During the screening phase, titles and abstracts were 
first independently evaluated following the eligibility cri-
teria. Eligibility was assessed independently in triplicate 
(A.M.M., T.M. and P.L.) with differences resolved by 
consensus when disagreements occurred. When abstracts 
did not provide sufficient information, they were selected 
for full-text evaluation. Full-text articles meeting criteria 
were retrieved and read independently by the researchers 
(A.M.M., T.M. and P.L.) and assessed for study inclusion.
2.3 Data Extraction and Endpoints
One researcher (P.L.) extracted data using a standard-
ised form. Relevant information extracted from studies 
included publication information (i.e. authors and year of 
publication), demographic and clinical characteristics such 
as age, body mass index (BMI) and health status (e.g. self-
reported physical disability, mobility-limited, sarcopenia 
and frailty), experimental design and sample size. Resist-
ance training prescription characteristics such as delivery, 
frequency, volume and intensity were extracted and used to 
categorise the resistance training programs as low (LVRT), 
moderate (MVRT) and high volume (HVRT) on the basis 
of terciles of prescribed weekly resistance training volume 
(i.e. product of frequency, number of exercises and number 
of sets) for full- and lower-body training.
The primary outcomes for physical function were fast 
walking speed, timed up and go and 6-min walking test. 
For muscle hypertrophy, we assessed lean body mass and 
lower-body muscle hypertrophy. With regards to muscle 
strength, leg press 1-RM, knee extension 1-RM, knee 
extension isometric strength and knee extension isoki-
netic test at 60° s−1 or 120° s−1 were recorded. If authors 
of the identified articles did not include dispersion values 
of change, the standard deviation (SD) of the change was 
calculated assuming a correlation of r = 0.5 between the 
baseline and post-intervention assessment measures [40]. 
Information was extracted from baseline versus < 20 weeks 
and/or ≥ 20 weeks post-intervention.
2.4 Risk of Bias Assessment and Certainty 
of Evidence (GRADE)
The risk of bias was evaluated according to the Cochrane 
risk-of-bias tool 2.0 (RoB 2) [41], with each assessment 
focused on the outcome level. The study quality assessment 
for all included studies was performed independently by two 
researchers (T.M. and A.M.M.), with disagreements resolved 
by consensus. The certainty of evidence for the network of 
interventions was assessed using the Grading of Recommen-
dations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) 
approach for network meta-analysis [42].
2.5 Data Synthesis and Analysis
Continuous outcome data in both pairwise and network 
meta-analyses (NMA) were summarised as standardised 
mean differences (SMD) and 95% confidence intervals 
(95% CI). All values used for analyses are presented in 
ESM Tables S1–S9. The frequentist NMA model was per -
formed following the current PRISMA guideline for NMA 
[43, 44]. All NMA analyses were conducted using the R 
package ‘netmeta’ [45]. A random-effects model was under-
taken to examine the effect of different resistance training 
volumes and controls. The between-study variability (i.e. 
heterogeneity) of the intervention effects within each inter -
vention comparison was assessed by I 2 and the magnitude 
of the between-study variance (τ 2) and estimated using the 
generalised DerSimonian–Laird estimator and the Q-profile 
approach. For each NMA, we assessed a priori the transitiv-
ity assumption, which implies that the distribution of the 
potential treatment effect modifiers is balanced across the 
available direct comparisons [46]. We used the percentage 
of male participants, average age, BMI, health status and 
overall risk of bias as potential intervention effect modifiers. 
We also evaluated each network for inconsistency globally 
using the random-effects design-by-treatment interaction 
model [47 ]. If the global test suggested inconsistency, we 
assessed inconsistency locally by splitting the direct and 
indirect evidence [48].
Comparisons were made when more than one study 
was included for each comparator. According to Hedges’ 
g, SMD values of 0.0 to ≤ 0.5 indicate small; 0.51–0.79, 
medium or moderate; and ≥ 0.8, large effects. Intervention 
effects were ranked according to P -scores [49 ]. Extreme-
study effects (i.e. outliers) were explored with the forward 
search (FS) algorithm [50] using the R package ‘NMAout-
lier’ [51]. When obvious outliers were detected, these were 
excluded in a sensitivity analysis to assess the robustness 
of results. A comparison-adjusted funnel plot was drawn to 
assess publication bias and small study effects when more 
than 10 studies were available. Subgroup NMA analyses 
were provided for intervention duration (i.e. < 20 weeks 

171
Resistance Training Volume Effects on Function, Morphology and Strength in Older Adults
and ≥ 20 weeks) and health status (i.e. physically healthy, 
physically impaired, mixed physically healthy and physi-
cally impaired).
3 Results
Following deletion of duplicates, a total of 4635 poten-
tial records were identified. Of these, 2695 records were 
excluded on the basis of titles and abstracts due to their 
irrelevance to the research question, resulting in 1940 
records deemed eligible for full-text review. A total of 
1813 reports were excluded for reasons listed in Fig.  1. 
After including 34 additional studies via reference lists 
[52– 85], a total of 161 articles [30, 32, 33, 86– 209] 
describing 151 randomised trials were included in the 
present systematic review and network meta-analysis.

3.1 Study, Participant and Intervention 
Characteristics
A total of 6306 participants (females, n = 3877; males, 
n = 1720; not reported, n = 709) were included with a 
median age of 68.8 [interquartile range (IQR) = 67.0; 72.4] 
years and BMI of 26.8 (IQR = 25.2; 28.0) kg m−2. Most of 
the studies included physically healthy participants (119 
out of 151 studies, 78.8%), followed by participants with 
sarcopenia (9 out of 119, 6.0%), mobility limitations (6 out 
of 119, 4.0%) and frailty (5 out of 119, 3.3%). A total of 12 
studies included both physically healthy participants and 
participants with physical disability (7.9%).
A total of 164 resistance training interventions from 
161 articles were analysed. The median intervention dura-
tion was 12 (IQR: 12; 20) weeks, with a median of 36 
(IQR: 24; 48) sessions. Most interventions (119, 72.6%) 
were short term (5–18 weeks), while fewer (45, 27.4%) 
were medium-to-long term (20–118 weeks). All studies 
reported resistance training volume, with a median of 
48 (IQR: 36; 72) weekly sets for whole-body resistance 
training, and 23 (IQR: 15; 30) weekly sets for lower-body 
resistance training. Peak intensity was reported for 141 
interventions (86.0%) with a median of 80% (IQR: 75%; 
80%) of the 1-RM. The median attendance was 92.0% 
(IQR: 84%; 96%), while the median dropout rate was 8.0% 
(IQR: 0%; 17.6%). A total of 146 studies were randomised 
controlled trials (96.7%), while five studies (3.3%) com-
pared different resistance training volumes without a con-
trol group. The characteristics of the individual studies are 
presented in ESM Table S10. The risk of bias assessment 
for each outcome is presented in ESM Tables S11–S14.
3.2 Network Meta‑analysis
Resistance training programs were categorised using ter -
ciles as low-volume (LVRT; total-body: 10 to < 42 weekly 
sets; lower limb: 5 to < 18 weekly sets), moderate-volume 
(MVRT; total-body: 42 to < 61 weekly sets; lower limb: 
18 to < 27 weekly sets) and high-volume resistance train-
ing (HVRT; total-body: ≥ 61 weekly sets; lower limb: ≥ 27 
weekly sets). Specifically, the LVRT group performed a 
median of 30 (IQR: 24; 36), the MVRT performed 48 
(IQR: 42; 54) and the HVRT group performed 72 (IQR: 
72; 84) full-body weekly sets. The LVRT group performed 
a median of 12 (IQR: 9; 15), the MVRT group performed 
21 (IQR: 18; 24) and the HVRT group performed 36 (IQR: 
27; 45) weekly sets for the lower body. The network geom-
etry of studies examining the physical function outcomes, 
lean body mass and lower-limb muscle hypertrophy and 
muscle strength outcomes is presented in ESM Figs. S1 
and S2.
3.2.1 Physical Function Outcomes
LVRT was the most effective for reducing the time to 
perform the timed up and go test [number of compari -
sons (k ) = 49; − 1.20 SMD, 95% CI: − 1.57 to − 0.82, 
P < 0.001; P-score = 94.4%] and improving 6-min walk 
(k = 21; 1.03 SMD, 95% CI: 0.33–1.73, P = 0.004; 
P-score = 81.9%) deriving large effects when compared 
with controls (Table  1). Despite the small effect, HVRT 
was the most effective program for increasing fast walking 
speed (k = 10; 0.40 SMD, 95% CI: 0.10–0.71, P = 0.010; 
P-score = 90.2%) compared with controls (Table  1). 
Subgroup NMAs for intervention duration and physical 
health status are presented in Figs.  2 and 3 , respectively. 
For timed up and go, LVRT resulted in significantly 
large effects in the short and medium-to-long term, while 
MVRT and HVRT only resulted in significant effects in 
the short term (Fig.  2b). For the 6-min walk test, both 
LVRT and MVRT resulted in significantly large effects 
in the short term (Fig.  2c). A significant effect on fast 
walking speed was only observed following HVRT in the 
short term (Fig.  2a). For physical health status, physically 
healthy participants derived significant effects on timed up 
and go (Fig.  3b) and the 6-min walk test following LVRT 
and MVRT (Fig.  3c). Results for physically impaired par -
ticipants were only available and significant for timed up 
and go following HVRT (Fig.  3a). 
The design-by-treatment interaction model showed no 
evidence of statistically significant inconsistency in the 
NMA for timed up and go (Q = 0.47, P = 0.791) and 6-min 
walk test (Q = 0.86, P = 0.652). Local side-split analyses 
are presented in ESM Table S15. Visual assessment of 
comparison-adjusted funnel plots (ESM Fig. S3) sug-
gested evidence of small-study effects for timed up and 
go (P = 0.039), but not 6-min walk test (P = 0.067) and 
fast walking speed (P = 0.910). The study by Fritz et al. 
[166] was detected as an outlier in the FS iteration 39 
for timed up and go and FS iteration 16 for the 6-min 
walk test. The identification of these outliers was based 
on the FS algorithm, which resulted in sharp changes in 
the ratio of variances, as presented in ESM Figs. S4 and 
S5. We conducted sensitivity analyses by excluding the 
outlier detected for both timed up and go [166] and 6-min 
walk test [166]. Sensitivity analyses results are presented 
in ESM Table S16. For timed up and go, the effect of 
MVRT was reduced from − 0.91 SMD to − 0.63 SMD, 
while the heterogeneity of the model was reduced (from 
78% to 68%). Sensitivity analyses for 6-min walk test did 
not change the results. Overall, the certainty of the evi-
dence was graded ‘low’ for fast walking speed, timed up 
and go and 6-min walk test.

173
Resistance Training Volume Effects on Function, Morphology and Strength in Older Adults
3.2.2 Lean Body Mass and Lower‑Limb Muscle Hypertrophy
All resistance training programs (k = 76) resulted in small 
increases in lean body mass compared with controls, 
with LVRT (0.25 SMD, 95% CI: 0.10–0.40, P = 0.001; 
P-score = 76.7%) and MVRT (0.24 SMD, 95% CI: 
0.13–0.36, P < 0.001; P-score = 75.3%) considered the most 
effective (Table 2). For lower-limb muscle hypertrophy, all 
resistance training programs were significantly effective 
compared with controls, with LVRT considered the most 
effective program (k = 45; 0.40 SMD, 95% CI: 0.25–0.54, 
P < 0.001; P-score = 94.2%; Table 2). Subgroup NMAs are 
presented in Figs. 4 and 5. LVRT resulted in a significantly 
small effect on lean mass in the short and medium-to-long 
term, while MVRT and HVRT were only statistically signifi-
cant in the short term (Fig. 4a). Improvements in lower-limb 
muscle hypertrophy were only observed following LVRT in 
the short and medium-to-long term and MVRT in the short 
term (Fig. 4b). For physical health status, physically healthy 
participants increased lean body mass (Fig.  5a) and lower-
limb muscle hypertrophy (Fig.  5b) following all resistance 
training volumes. Results for physically impaired partici-
pants were only available and statistically significant for lean 
body mass following MVRT (Fig. 5a). 
The design-by-treatment interaction model showed no 
evidence of statistically significant inconsistency in the 
NMA for lean body mass (Q = 3.30, P = 0.986) or lower-limb 
muscle hypertrophy ( Q = 2.47, P = 0.650). Local side-split 
analyses are presented in ESM Table S17. Visual assessment 
of comparison-adjusted funnel plots (ESM Fig. S6) sug-
gested no evidence of small-study effects for lean body mass 
(P = 0.096) and lower-limb muscle hypertrophy (P = 0.588). 
The FS algorithm provided an outlier [155] in lower-limb 
muscle hypertrophy (ESM Fig. S7). Sensitivity analyses

while HVRT resulted in a large effect on knee extension

group analyses for intervention duration and physical health 
status are presented in Figs.  6 and 7, respectively. Results 
were statistically significant following all resistance training 
volumes in the short and medium-to-long term for all muscle 
strength outcomes (Fig.  6), except for the effects of LVRT 
on knee extension isometric strength in the medium-to-long 
term (Fig. 6c). Evidence was unavailable for knee extension 
isokinetic torque in the medium-to-long term. Physically 
healthy participants derived significant effects on muscle 
strength outcomes following all resistance training volumes 
(Fig. 7), except for knee extension isokinetic torque follow-
ing LVRT, for which evidence was not available. Physically 
impaired participants benefited from LVRT and MVRT on 
knee extension 1-RM (Fig.  7a), leg press 1-RM (Fig.  7b) 
and from LVRT and HVRT on knee extension isometric 
strength (Fig. 7c). 
The design-by-treatment interaction model showed no 
evidence of statistically significant inconsistency in the 
NMA for knee extension 1-RM (Q = 3.74, P = 0.928), leg 
press 1-RM (Q = 0.69, P = 0.995), knee extension isomet-
ric strength (Q = 0.08, P = 0.960) and isokinetic torque 
(Q = 0.45, P = 0.503). Local side-split analyses are pre-
sented in ESM Table S19. Visual assessment of comparison-
adjusted funnel plots (ESM Fig. S8) suggested evidence of 
small-study effects for knee extension 1-RM (P < 0.001), leg 
press 1-RM (P < 0.001), knee extension isometric strength 
(P < 0.001) and isokinetic torque (P = 0.015). For knee 
extension isometric strength, an outlier [131] was detected 
at the interaction 31 of FS algorithm due to sharp changes 
in the ratio of variances (ESM Fig. S9). After omitting the 
outlier, results were not different from the primary analyses 
(ESM Table S20). On the basis of the GRADE approach, 
the certainty of evidence was considered ‘very low’ for all 
muscle strength outcomes.
4
sections.discussion:
We aimed to determine the most effective resistance training 
volume to improve physical function, lean body mass and 
lower-body muscle hypertrophy and strength in older adults 
aged ≥ 60 years. In addition, we examined whether inter -
vention duration and physical health status moderate such 
effects. Even though we observed significant improvements 
across all resistance training volumes compared with no 
physical exercise, a low resistance training volume proved 
highly effective in improving timed up and go, lean mass and 
muscle hypertrophy. Except for muscle strength, prescribing 
a high resistance training volume did not accrue additional 
benefits for the outcomes examined. Regarding the modera-
tors tested, our results were independent of program duration 
and mainly observed for healthy older adults, while evidence 
was limited for those who were physically impaired. There-
fore, our findings are that a low resistance training volume 
can substantially improve healthy older adults’ physical 
function and benefits lean mass and muscle size indepen-
dently of program duration, while a higher volume seems to 
be necessary for achieving greater improvements in muscle 
strength.
The present review indicates that a low volume of resist-
ance training, median of ~ 12 weekly sets for lower limb 
muscles, equivalent to two sessions per week and two sets

per exercise for three lower-limb resistance training exer -
cises, has proven highly effective in enhancing physical 
function measured by timed up and go and 6-min walk test 
but not fast walking speed in healthy older adults. The same 
was not observed in the previous meta-analysis of Rocha 
et al. [26]. The reason may be related to the different meta-
analysis design (network versus pairwise) and the combina-
tion of physical function outcomes in a single analysis in 
Rocha et al. [26]. It should be noted that physical function 
benefits derived from resistance training are test depend -
ent, which is why resistance training effects are mostly 
test-specific and training prescription should be individu-
alised in older adults [210]. While the exact reasons remain 
unclear, we propose that the positive effects of resistance 
training on physical function may not be linear, as they do 
not increase further beyond a certain resistance training 
dosage. In regard to fast walking speed, a previous study 
also observed greater improvements in fast walking speed 
following a high-volume resistance training compared with 
a low-volume resistance training [211]. However, the pre-
vious review by Beijersbergen et al. [212] indicated that

Resistance Training Volume Effects on Function, Morphology and Strength in Older Adults
improvements in walking speed are unclear and poorly cor-
related with muscle strength improvements. As a result, 
more studies are required to explore the effects of resistance 
training dosage on the physiological mechanisms involved 
in walking speed adaptations. Nevertheless, as seen in this 
study, a minimum amount of 12 lower-limb weekly sets 
(approximately 8–10 repetitions per set) may be enough 
and worth recommending for future resistance training 
guidelines for older adults. This finding is critical due to the 
well-known barriers to engaging in exercise programs, such 
as limited time and convenience [213, 214], affecting adher-
ence to current physical activity recommendations for older 
adults [215]. A low-volume workout for the lower limbs can 
be completed in less than 20 min, providing opportunities 
to incorporate other components associated with healthy 
ageing such as aerobic and balance exercises [10, 11, 216]. 
Additionally, we observed that the benefits from a low resist-
ance training volume in the short term persist over longer 
periods, and a higher resistance training volume was not 
necessary for continuous improvement in timed up and go. 
However, it is important to note that our results mainly apply 
to physically healthy participants, indicating the potential 
benefits of a low-volume program for preventing mobility 
disability. As a result, untrained older adults engaging in a 
low-volume program may preserve important components 
of daily living [28] while attenuating age-related declines in 
physical function and maintaining healthy ageing.
A low volume of resistance training also proved highly 
effective in enhancing lean body mass and promoting lower-
body muscle hypertrophy. Our results were partially similar 
to the results of Marques et al. [ 27] and Rocha et al. [ 26], 
indicating that both low- and high-volume resistance train-
ing may result in similar increases in lean body mass. In 
contrast, our results concur and extend the findings from our 
previous network meta-analysis [217] and the study by Cur-
rier et al. [218]. As noted previously across the spectrum of

180 R. Radaelli et al.
resistance training intensities [217, 218], it seems that once 
a certain volume threshold is surpassed, resistance training 
improves lean mass and lower-body muscle hypertrophy 
independently of the dosage. We observed median increases 
ranging from 0.6 to 0.8 kg in lean mass. Our results partially 
concur with current recommendations [9–11], indicating that 
an even lower resistance training volume than previously 
suggested for muscle function and size improvement can 
be sustained for longer periods (≥ 20 weeks). Interestingly, 
adopting a low volume resistance training program with ~ 30 
full-body weekly sets (or ~ 12 lower-limb weekly sets) led 
to slightly superior benefits and was the only program to 
result in continuous improvements over the medium-to-
long term. Furthermore, the relatively modest effects and 
lack of continuous improvement in these outcomes were 
observed in previous studies [18, 219, 220] and seem to 
be associated with anabolic resistance [18, 219, 220], as 
we previously observed [221], and the diminishing returns 
principle, respectively. Nonetheless, low-volume resistance 
training may be an interesting strategy to help participants 
stay motivated, build on compliance and achieve their goals, 
especially considering the challenges of long-term adher -
ence to resistance training and dropouts in participation 
in physical activity programs over time. Regarding those 
who may derive these benefits, our results were predomi-
nantly observed in physically healthy participants. This was 
expected, given that the current evidence is limited for those 
at higher risk of disability [222–224]. While resistance train-
ing can prevent muscle wasting in older adults with sar -
copenia or frailty [222– 224], the most effective resistance 
training dosage for this group remains to be determined.
Regarding muscle strength, all resistance training vol-
umes resulted in large effects on knee extension and leg 
press 1-RM. While we did not directly measure the impact of 
resistance training intensity, which is highly associated with 
gains in muscle strength [217, 225], the studies we examined 
had predominantly prescribed a peak intensity of at least 
80% of the 1-RM. The principle of training specificity [226] 
explains the large effects on 1-RM outcomes, as most partic-
ipants trained more closely to the requirement for the 1-RM

181
Resistance Training Volume Effects on Function, Morphology and Strength in Older Adults
test and presented greater transfer. However, a moderate-
to-high volume was associated with greater improvements 
in isometric muscle strength and isokinetic torque. This 
result seems to be similar to the results of Rocha et al. [26], 
although these authors combined different measures of mus-
cle strength in the same analysis. For greater improvements 
in non-specific muscle strength, these were likely attributed 
to volume rather than peak intensity, with a higher dosage 
associated with greater changes in isometric strength and 
isokinetic torque. Nevertheless, gains in knee extension and 
leg press muscle strength following higher volumes, regard-
less of muscle strength type, were not specifically associ-
ated with gains in the physical function tests investigated. A 
nonlinear association between muscle strength and physi-
cal function has been previously noted [227]. Therefore, 
when muscle strength reaches a certain threshold, likely 
achieved following different resistance training volumes, 
further increases do not contribute to better physical func-
tion. Regarding the moderators tested, results were consist-
ently observed in the short and medium-to-long term, with a 
moderate-to-high resistance training volume associated with 
greater improvements. Interestingly, both physically healthy 
and physically impaired participants derived significantly 
large effects from moderate-to-high resistance training vol-
ume, which is important to preserve muscle strength for 
those targeting healthy ageing and achieve a greater safety 
margin before the threshold for disabilities.
As far as we know, this systematic review and network 
meta-analysis represents the largest synthesis of resistance 
training volume in older adults. The strengths of the present 
study are as follows: (i) the inclusion of 151 randomised 
trials with 6306 older adults (≥ 60 years), (ii) a network 
meta-analysis comparing well-defined ranges of resist-
ance training volumes and (iii) resistance training studies 
without interference from other exercise components. How-
ever, there are limitations worthy of comment. First, most 
studies had a high risk of bias. Several concerns regarding 
the randomisation process, measurement of outcomes and 
selection of reported results were identified. Transparency 
about randomisation, allocation aspects and more rigorous 
assessments of outcomes must be considered in future resist-
ance training trials in older adults to reduce bias, achieve 
a high certainty of evidence and better inform guidelines 
and health professionals. Second, most studies were con-
ducted in the short term (72.6%) and included older adults 
who were deemed physically healthy (78.8%). These fac-
tors have limited the generalisability of the data to longer 
periods and older adults with physical limitations. Third, 
we did not account for the specific number of repetitions 
prescribed/performed or tempo to calculate the resistance 
training volume, which are other methods to calculate 
the total volume. Given the high variability and ranges of 
repetitions prescribed in the studies examined and lack of 
reporting of resistance training tempo, an estimation and 
inclusion of these measures to calculate the resistance train-
ing volume would be imprecise and likely misleading in the 
current context. Fourth, we did not account for the effects 
of resistance training compliance (i.e. ratio of the total vol-
ume of resistance training completed to that prescribed). It 
is expected that participants will present reduced compli-
ance in long-term programs, and this could affect physical 
function, muscle hypertrophy and strength adaptations in the 
long term. Finally, our findings for fast walking speed were 
limited by the small number of studies (n = 11) and lack of 
direct comparisons between the resistance training volumes 
investigated.
5 Conclusions
In summary, our findings indicated that a low volume is 
highly effective for enhancing physical function, lean 
mass and muscle size in older adults in the short term 
(< 20  weeks). This approach was also effective in the 
medium-to-long term (≥ 20 weeks). While prescribing a 
high resistance training volume may result in additional 
benefits for muscle strength, our study suggests that a lower 
resistance training volume, approximately ~ 30 full-body 
weekly sets (or ~ 12 lower-limb weekly sets), equivalent to 
two sessions per week and two sets per exercise for eight 
lower-limb resistance exercises, is a reasonable and feasible 
amount of resistance exercise. This volume of resistance 
training should be recommended in future exercise guide-
lines, particularly for physically healthy older adults target-
ing healthy ageing.
